questions.text: Cerebriform appearance of T-lymphocytes is classically seen in which of the following malignancies?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Mycosis Fungoides

 

Option B:

 

  • Cerebriform appearance of T-lymphocytes is seen in Mycosis fungoides (MF). Cerebriform appearance is also seen in Sezary syndrome.
  • Mycosis fungoides is derived from skin-resident effector memory T cells, whereas Sezary syndrome is derived from central memory T cells.
  • Below image depicts these T lymphocytes having Cerebriform appearance.

 

 

  • Mycosis fungoides is the most common type of primary cutaneous T cell lymphoma.

 

Histopathology findings:

 

  • ﻿﻿Epidermotropism - presence of lymphocytes in the epidermal cells.
  • ﻿﻿Pautrier’s micro abscesses consisting of clusters of atypical lymphocytes.
  • ﻿﻿Atypical T lymphocytes have a cerebriform appearance with an irregular nuclear outline and halo around cells.

 

Management of MF: Extracorporeal Photopheresis

 

  • The clinical triad of Sezary syndrome consists of the following: (can be remembered with mnemonic SLE)

 

  1. ﻿﻿﻿Atypical mononuclear cells (Sezary cells) comprising more than 20% of total lymphocyte count or total
    Sezary count of more than 1000 × 109 /L
  2. Peripheral Lymphadenopathy
  3. Erythroderma - As a result of diffuse infiltration of the skin by neoplastic cells

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Pseudolymphoma:

 

  • This term is used to describe a group of benign disorders that mimic lymphomas clinically and histologically but are not true lymphomas. T-lymphocytes in pseudolymphoma do not typically show cerebriform nuclei.

 

Option C. Adult T Cell Leukaemia:

 

  • This is a type of leukemia caused by the human T-cell lymphotropic virus (HTLV-1). Although it involves T-lymphocytes, the cells do not have the classic cerebriform nuclei seen in Mycosis Fungoides.

 

Option D. Chronic Myeloid Leukaemia:

 

  • This is a type of blood cancer that typically affects the myeloid lineage of white blood cells and does not involve T-lymphocytes with cerebriform nuclei.

 

﻿﻿﻿Educational Objective:

 

  • The Cerebriform appearance of T-lymphocytes is a characteristic feature of Mycosis fungoides, a form of cutaneous T-cell lymphoma.

 

Ref: Rook's Textbook of Dermatology 9th Edition, Chapter 140, Page No 140.1 – 140.20

choices.text: Nodular Type is the commonest clinical presentation in this condition.
PUVA Therapy is a risk factor for this condition.
Early Diagnosis in Pre-Malignant Stage is crucial for the prognosis of this condition.

questions.text: A 60-year-old male presented with a cancerous growth on his face. A diagnosis of Basal Cell Carcinoma is made based on Biopsy findings which showed characteristic peripheral palisading of tumour cells. Which of the following statements is INCORRECT regarding this condition?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Early Diagnosis in Pre-Malignant Stage is crucial for the prognosis of this condition.

 

Option C:

  • Basal cell carcinoma typically has no premalignant stage.

 

Explanation:

 

Basal Cell Carcinoma

  • Clinical features: Presents as Pearly translucent nodule with surface telangiectasia, undergoes central necrosis resulting in rodent ulcer with a rolled-out margin.
  • Nodular type is the commonest clinical type of basal cell carcinoma. Below image depicts the Nodular Basal Cell Carcinoma (Option A)

 

 

  • Metastasis in basal cell carcinoma is extremely rare. The typical basal cell carcinoma develops slowly and extends to the periphery. (Option D)

 

The following are the risk factors for basal cell carcinoma:

 

  • ﻿﻿Solar Radiation
  • ﻿﻿Psoralen-UVA Therapy (PUVA) (Option B)
  • ﻿﻿Human Papilloma Virus infections
  • ﻿﻿latrogenic Infections
  • ﻿﻿Surgical Scar
  • ﻿﻿UV-B Rays
  • ﻿﻿lonising Radiation
  • ﻿﻿Photosensitising Drugs
  • ﻿﻿Previous history of Basal Cell Carcinoma

 

  • Histopathology: The tumour cells resemble cells of stratum basale that have grown into the dermis & shows a characteristic peripheral palisading of tumour cells

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Basal Cell Carcinoma (BCC) is a locally invasive skin cancer that rarely metastasizes. Early diagnosis and treatment are crucial to prevent local tissue damage and disfigurement caused by the tumor's growth.

 

Ref: Rook's Textbook of Dermatology - 9th Edition - Volume IV Chapter 141, Page no 141.1 – 141.16

choices.text: Keratoacanthoma is a Premalignant Lesion of Squamous Cell Carcinoma
Actinic Keratosis has Low Risk of progression to Squamous Cell Carcinoma
Bowen's Disease has Low Potential for Invasive Malignancy
Verrucous Carcinoma is a Well-Differentiated Squamous Cell Carcinoma.

questions.text: Identify the INCORRECT statement among the following options?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Keratoacanthoma is a Premalignant Lesion of Squamous Cell Carcinoma

 

Option A:

 

  • Keratoacanthoma is considered a form of well-differentiated squamous cell carcinoma, it is not a premalignant condition.

 

Explanation:

 

Option B.

 

  • Actinic keratoses are hyperkeratotic lesions that develop on adult skin that has been exposed to UV rays over an extended period of time and have a low risk of developing into invasive squamous cell carcinoma.

 

Option C.

 

  • Bowen's disease is a slow growing papulosquamous lesion which has a low potential for invasive malignancy.
  • Image below depicts Bowens disease lesion.

 

 

  • It usually grows progressively but sometimes undergoes spontaneous partial resolution. It can occur anywhere, but it occurs more in the head and neck region.

 

Option D.

 

  • Verrucous carcinoma is a well-differentiated squamous cell carcinoma.
  • It is slow-growing, and it rarely metastasizes.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Keratoacanthoma is often considered a low-grade variant of SCC rather than a premalignant lesion, actinic keratosis has a low but significant risk of progression to SCC, Bowen's disease is an early form of SCC with low but present risk of invasion, and verrucous carcinoma is a well-differentiated form of SCC with low metastatic potential but potential for local aggression.

 

Ref: Rook's Textbook of Dermatology 9th Edition, Chapter 142, Page Nos 142.1-142.28

questions.text: What long-term complication is most likely to occur in this patient having this lesion since birth:
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Malignant Melanoma.

 

Option C:

 

  • This is an image showing Hyperpigmented lesion covered by hair which is present since birth, suggestive of Congenital melanocytic nevus & Giant congenital melanocytic nevus (> 20cms size) has 2-5% risk of melanoma.

 

Risk Factors for Malignant Melanoma (MM) are as follows:

 

  • ﻿﻿Family history
  • ﻿﻿Melanocytic nevus- may be congenital nevus (>20 cm – Giant congenital melanocytic nevus has 2-5% risk of melanoma)
  •  or atypical/dysplastic nevus
  • ﻿﻿Genetic mutations- mutations of CDKN2A gene (major susceptibility), MC1R gene (moderate susceptibility), TYR gene (low susceptibility)
  • ﻿﻿Fitzpatrick's Skin type I has two-fold increased risk as compared to type IV.
  • ﻿﻿Sun exposure

 

Clinical Features:

 

  • The majority of melanoma cases (about 70%) are of the superficial spreading type, which typically develops in pre-existing nevi.

 

 

Types of Melanomas:

 

  1. ﻿﻿﻿Superficial Spreading Melanoma
  2. ﻿﻿﻿Lentigo Maligna Melanoma
  3. ﻿﻿﻿Acral Lentiginous Melanoma
  4. ﻿﻿﻿Nodular Melanoma

 

Prognosis:

 

  • Tumour thickness or Breslow index is the best prognostic factor of melanoma.
  • It is the distance in millimetres (mm) between the epidermal granular layer and the deepest level of invasion of the primary lesion.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Cataract:

 

  • This is characterized by clouding of the lens within the eye, leading to a decrease in vision. It is not related to skin lesions such as a congenital melanocytic nevus.

 

Option B:

 

  • Sturge-Weber Syndrome (SWS) often leads to secondary glaucoma due to vascular malformations affecting eye drainage, with facial involvement increasing the risk.
  • SWS presents clinically as Port wine stain.

 

Port Wine Stain

 

  • Features: Also known as nevus flammeus, it is a capillary malformation that presents as a flat, pink, red, or purplish mark. It remains unchanged throughout life and can be anywhere on the body but is often seen on the face as shown below in the image.

 

 

Managing SWS-related glaucoma requires a multidisciplinary approach and regular eye exams for early detection and vision preservation.

 

Option D. Basal cell carcinoma:

 

  • This is the most common form of skin cancer, often associated with long-term sun exposure. It typically appears as a raised, pearly bump and does not usually develop from congenital melanocytic nevi.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Congenital melanocytic nevi, especially larger ones, carry an increased risk for the development of malignant melanoma.
  • Monitoring and possibly biopsy of suspicious changes within these nevi are important for early detection of malignant transformation.

 

Ref: Rooks Textbook of Dermatology 9th Edition Page Number 75.9 to 75.14 73.2, 73.3, 143.2, 143.16

choices.text: Squamous Cell Carcinoma
Basal Cell Carcinoma

questions.text: A 33-year-old truck driver who is a HIV positive, presents with the following lesion on his palate as shown in the below image, which has progressed in size from the time he first noticed them. What is your diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Kaposi Sarcoma

 

Option B:

 

  • The above image shows multipleplaque-like lesions coalescing with each other which is suggestive of Kaposi sarcoma. All forms of Kaposi sarcoma are associated with HHV 8 infection as an aetiological agent.
  • It is a multifocal, endothelial proliferation most often with cutaneous involvement (Skin lesions are usually purple and multifocal which eventually evolve into plaques and tumours) and with or without visceral extension. This virus is transmitted through saliva and blood products.
  • It is mostly seen in Extremities, commonly on feet and occasionally on hands, ears, and nose, Lymph nodes, mucosae, and viscera may be involved as the disease progresses, although this can occur without skin involvement.
  • It has a low-grade malignant potential. The most important cofactor associated is HIV co-infection which increases the risk up to 20,000-fold.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Squamous Cell Carcinoma –

 

  • Squamous Cell Carcinoma (SCC) in the oral cavity often presents as a non-healing ulcer or mass with keratinization.
  • It is associated with risk factors like tobacco and alcohol use.
  • This patient's HIV-positive status and the appearance of the lesions are less typical for SCC, which tends to be more localized and less vascular in appearance.

 

Option C. Basal Cell Carcinoma –

 

  • Basal cell carcinoma (BCC) is the most common skin cancer, characterized by pearly papules with telangiectasia and a propensity for local invasion.
  • It is extremely rare in the oral cavity because it usually occurs in areas of the skin that are exposed to the sun.
  • The lesion in the image is not consistent with the typical presentation of BCC.

 

Option D. Melanoma –

 

  • Melanoma in the oral cavity is rare and would typically present as a rapidly expanding, darkly pigmented lesion. The lesion in the image lacks the dark pigmentation that is commonly seen with melanoma. Additionally, melanoma tends to be more aggressive and less likely to present as multiple lesions in early stages.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • In HIV-positive patients, a palatal lesion that is vascular in appearance and has progressed in size is most consistent with Kaposi sarcoma, particularly in the context of immune suppression and the absence of typical features of other listed conditions.

 

Ref: Rook's Textbook of Dermatology - 9th Edition - Volume IV Chapter 139 Page No 139.1

questions.text: A 50-year-old male presented with sudden eruption of asymptomatic lesions as shown in the picture below. The lesions had a Stuck-on appearance suggestive of a diagnosis of Seborrheic keratosis. Which of the following malignancy should we suspect given that there was a sudden eruption of these lesions over body?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Gastric

 

Option A.

 

  • A sudden eruption of multiple seborrheic keratosis lesions, known as the sign of Leser-Trélat, can be a paraneoplastic syndrome typically associated with gastric adenocarcinoma.
  • However, it can also be associated with other internal malignancies.

 

Explanation:

 

Option B. Intestinal:

 

  • While Leser-Trélat can be associated with various internal malignancies, gastric adenocarcinoma is the classic association.
  • Intestinal cancers can sometimes present with this sign, but they are not the most commonly associated malignancy.

 

Option C. Lungs:

 

  • Lung cancer can be associated with various paraneoplastic syndromes, but Leser-Trélat is more classically linked with gastric adenocarcinoma.

 

Option D. Heart:

 

  • There is no established association between cardiac malignancies and the sign of Leser-Trélat. Heart cancers are extremely rare and typically do not present with dermatologic paraneoplastic syndromes.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • The sudden appearance of multiple seborrheic keratosis lesions, known as the sign of Leser-Trélat, is suggestive of an underlying malignancy, most classically gastric adenocarcinoma.
  • This sign should prompt a thorough investigation for Internal Malignancy.

 

Ref: Rooks Textbook of Dermatology- 9th Edition Page No 133.2

choices.text: Can be associated with Insulin Resistant Diabetes Mellitus
Can be an indication of underlying Gastric Adenocarcinoma
Lesions are described as having Velvety Texture with Hyperpigmented and Coarse Skin
Oral Contraceptive Pills intake is the most common cause

questions.text: All of the following statements are true regarding the condition shown in the image EXCEPT?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Oral Contraceptive Pills intake is the most common cause

 

Option D.

 

  • The most common cause of Acanthosis Nigricans is obesity and insulin resistance.
  • While hormonal medications, including oral contraceptive pills, can be associated with Acanthosis nigricans, they are not the most common cause.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Can be associated with Insulin resistant diabetes mellitus:

 

  • The condition shown in the image, Acanthosis nigricans, is often associated with insulin resistance, and consequently, it can be a marker for diabetes mellitus, especially Type 2 diabetes.

 

Option B. Can be an indication of underlying Gastric adenocarcinoma:

 

  • While less common, Acanthosis nigricans can be a paraneoplastic syndrome associated with internal malignancies, such as gastric adenocarcinoma.

 

Option C. Lesions are described as having velvety texture with hyperpigmented and coarse skin:

 

  • The hallmark of Acanthosis nigricans is hyperpigmented, coarse, and velvety plaques, typically found in body folds such as the neck and axillae.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Acanthosis nigricans is a dermatologic condition that is primarily associated with insulin resistance and obesity. It can also be a sign of underlying malignancy but is not most commonly caused by oral contraceptive pills.
  • The characteristic lesions have a velvety texture and are typically hyperpigmented.

 

Ref: Rooks Textbook of Dermatology- 9th Edition Page No 147

questions.text: Based on the Image, a 60-year-old male patient with Diabetes presents with Progressive Skin Lesions. What could be the likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Basal Cell Carcinoma

 

Option B:

 

  • The image above displays a central rodent ulcer, which indicates basal cell carcinoma. This malignant tumor exhibits characteristics of slow local invasion and mainly affects the pilosebaceous skin.

 

Basal Cell Carcinoma (BCC):

 

  • The most significant predisposing factor for basal cell carcinoma is exposure to ultraviolet radiation. Other risk factors include ionizing radiation, coal tar, aromatic hydrocarbons, and arsenic exposure.
  • Basal cell carcinoma predominantly affects middle-aged or elderly men with a history of excessive sun exposure, often among individuals with white skin, aged between 40 to 80 years.

 

Morphologically, basal cell carcinoma can be of 2 types:

 

  1. Localized Types: These are more common and include:
  • Nodular and nodulocystic BCC: Representing the majority of cases, these appear as pearly, waxy nodules with rolled borders and sometimes central ulceration or depression, known as umbilication.


     
  • Pigmented BCC: These are similar to nodular BCC but contain melanin, giving them a darker appearance.
  • Nevoid BCC: This type is rarer and can resemble benign moles.

 

  1. Generalized types: These are less common and can be more challenging to treat due to their growth patterns:

 

  • Superficial multifocal and spreading BCC: Often appearing as scaly, erythematous patches that can be mistaken for eczema or psoriasis.
  • Infiltrative BCC: These grow more aggressively and can invade deeper tissues.
  • Cicatrizing (or sclerosing) BCC: This type can cause scarring as it grows.

 

  • While nodular BCC is the most common form, it is important for medical practitioners to recognize the less common types due to their growth patterns and potential for tissue destruction.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Squamous cell carcinoma (SCC)

 

  • It typically presents as a firm, red nodule or a flat sore with a scaly crust as seen in the image below.
  • While it's possible for diabetic patients to develop SCC, the description provided fits BCC more closely.

 

Option C. Melasma

 

  • It is characterized by brown to gray-brown patches as seen in the image below.

 

 

  • It is usually seen on the face.
  • It is more common in women, especially during pregnancy, and is not typically associated with progressive lesions.

 

Option D. Discoid lupus erythematosus

 

  • It often presents as a chronic rash with red, inflamed, and scaly patches that can cause scarring, usually on the face, ears, and scalp, as seen in the image below.

 

 

  • It is an autoimmune condition and not directly linked to diabetes.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • In an elderly patient, progressive pearly or waxy skin lesions, especially if located on sun-exposed areas, are likely indicative of Basal Cell Carcinoma.

 

Ref: Rook’s Textbook of Dermatology -9th Edition Page No 4.15, 51.3, 88.10-12, 141.1-16

Robbins Basic Pathology 10th Edition Page No 1148

Bailey & Loves Short Practice of Surgery 27th Edition Page No 599, 604-6011

questions.text: Edges of a Basal Cell Carcinoma Lesion are described as?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Rolled out beaded.

 

Option A:

 

  • " Rolled out beaded " describes the edges of a Basal Cell Carcinoma (BCC) lesion.

 

 

  • The presence of telangiectasia within the ulcer is characteristic.

 

Option B. Sloping:

 

  • Sloping edges are associated with a healing, shallow ulcer, which is not typical of BCC.

 

 

  • This description is more likely to be seen in venous ulcers.

 

Option C. Punched out:

 

  • "Punched-out" refers to full-thickness skin death with a relatively quick onset, often seen in arterial or neuropathic ulcers, not BCC.

 

 

Option D. Undermined:

 

  • Undermined edges suggest an infection at the ulcer site that damages subcutaneous tissue.

 

 

  • This is not a feature of BCC but is indicative of an infectious process like Cutaneous Tuberculosis.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Recognize that Basal Cell Carcinoma is characterized by pearly rolled edges, which are indicative of the slow-growing nature of the tumour, along with the presence of telangiectasia. Top of Form

 

Ref: Rooks Textbook of Dermatology- 9th Edition Page No 141.8

questions.text: A 50-year-old patient presents with a chronic, pruritic rash composed of erythematous patches and plaques. Histological examination of a skin biopsy shows clusters of atypical lymphocytes within intraepidermal abscesses. What is this histopathological finding known as?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Pautrier's microabscesses 

 

Option C:

 

• These are a diagnostic histopathological feature of mycosis fungoides, a type of cutaneous T-cell lymphoma.

• They consist of collections of atypical lymphocytes within the epidermis, often without any associated spongiosis

 

Explanation:

Option A) Munro's microabscesses

• These are collections of neutrophils within the stratum corneum and are typically found in psoriasis, not mycosis fungoides.

Option B) Spongiform Pustules of Kogoj

• These are also associated with psoriasis and represent a spongiform collection of neutrophils in the epidermis.

 

Option D) Papillary Tip Microabscesses

• These are typically seen in dermatitis herpetiformis and consist of neutrophils at the tips of dermal papillae, usually accompanied by granular deposits of IgA.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Pautrier's microabscesses are a hallmark histopathological feature of mycosis fungoides, which are characterized by clusters of atypical lymphocytes within the epidermis.

 

Ref: Rooks Textbook of Dermatology- 9th Edition: page no 140.7

choices.text: Squamous Cell Carcinoma
Basal Cell Carcinoma

questions.text: A Female patient presented with a lesion as shown in the image below. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Melanoma.

 

Option B.

 

  • It is characterized by the ABCDE criteria: Asymmetry, Irregular Borders, Multiple Colours, Diameter greater than 6 mm, and Evolution over time.
  • The lesion in the image shows several of these features, making melanoma the most likely diagnosis.
  • Types of melanomas: Lentigo Maligna, Superficial Spreading, Acral Lentiginous, Nodular.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Squamous Cell Carcinoma

 

  • It typically presents as a crusted or scaly area of skin with a red, inflamed base, which may bleed easily.

 

 

  • It can also develop from a pre-existing actinic keratosis and is less likely to show the diverse pigmentation seen in the image.

 

Option C. Basal Cell Carcinoma

 

  • It often appears as a pearly or waxy bump, sometimes with visible blood vessels, mostly on sun-exposed areas of the body.

 

 

 

 

  • It does not typically present with the same level of pigmentation variation as seen in the image.

 

Option D. Seborrheic Keratosis

 

  • This is a benign skin growth that usually presents as a brown, black, or light tan growth on the face, chest, shoulders, or back.
  • The surface appears waxy, and it often looks like it is stuck onto the skin rather than being part of it.
  • It does not typically have the irregular borders or color variations associated with melanoma.

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Melanoma can be identified using the ABCDE criteria, which describe the asymmetry, border irregularity, colour variation, diameter, and evolving nature of pigmented lesions.

 

Ref: Bolognia Dermatology Textbook 4th Edition Page No 1991

Rooks’ Textbook of Dermatology- 9th Edition Page No 4.20-4.21, 144.1-144.5

Robbins & Cotran Pathologic Basis of Disease, 9th Edition Page No 1147-1150

Schwartz’s Principles of Surgery 10th Edition Page No 488

choices.text: Clark's level of invasion
Horizontal spread of melanoma

questions.text: In the staging of malignant melanoma, which measurement is considered superior for determining the prognosis due to its higher accuracy in predicting outcomes?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Breslow thickness

 

Option C.

 

  • It measures the depth of invasion of a melanoma in millimeters from the top of the granular layer of the epidermis down to the deepest point of tumor penetration.

  • It is a more accurate prognostic indicator than Clark's level because it gives a precise measurement of tumor thickness, which correlates directly with the likelihood of metastasis and survival.

Explanation:

 

Option A) Clark's level

 

• This categorizes the depth of melanoma into five levels based on anatomic landmarks.

• While it provides useful prognostic information, it is not as precise as Breslow thickness and can be subjective.

Option B) Horizontal spread of melanoma

 

• This can indicate the potential for local tissue destruction but does not directly correlate with the risk of metastasis and survival as accurately as Breslow thickness.

 

Option D) The presence of ulceration

 

• This is an important prognostic factor in melanoma but does not provide a direct measurement of tumor depth like Breslow thickness does.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Breslow thickness is a key prognostic indicator in the staging of malignant melanoma, as it provides a more accurate prediction of metastatic potential and patient survival than Clark's level of invasion.

 

Ref: Bolognia Dermatology Textbook 4th Edition Page No 1991

Rooks’ Textbook of Dermatology- 9th Edition Page No 4.20-4.21, 144.1-144.5

Robbins & Cotran Pathologic Basis of Disease, 9th Edition Page No 1147-1150

Schwartz’s Principles of Surgery 10th Edition Page No 488

questions.text: A 60-year-old male presents with erythroderma, generalized lymphadenopathy, and atypical circulating T-cells with cerebriform nuclei. A skin biopsy shows infiltration by neoplastic cells in the epidermis forming Pautriersmicro abscesses. Flow cytometry of peripheral blood reveals a CD4 to CD8 ratio greater than 10:1 with CD4+ T-cells exhibiting loss of CD7 expression. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Sézary Syndrome.

 

Option D.

 

  • Sézary syndrome is an aggressive form of cutaneous T-cell lymphoma characterized by erythroderma, lymphadenopathy, and the presence of malignant T-cells in the skin, lymph nodes, and peripheral blood, matching the presentation in the question.

 

 

Sezary Cells: Atypical circulating T-cells with cerebriform nuclei

 

Sezary Syndrome → Triad: (SLE)

 

  1. Circulating Sezary cells (Atypical Mononuclear Cells) >20% of Total Lymphocyte Count or 1000 X 109/L
  2. Generalized Lymphadenopathy
  3. Erythroderma (4th Stage of Mycosis Fungoides)

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Glucagonoma Syndrome:

 

  • Glucagonoma syndrome is associated with a glucagon-secreting pancreatic tumor and presents with necrolytic migratory erythema, weight loss, and diabetes, not with the features described in the question.
     

 

 

Necrolytic migratory erythema depicted in the above image

 

Option B. Mycosis Fungoides:

 

  • Mycosis fungoides is the most common form of cutaneous T-cell lymphoma and can present with similar skin findings but is typically limited to the skin without the prominent circulating atypical T-cells found in Sézary syndrome.

 

Option C. Basal Cell Carcinoma (BCC):

 

  • BCC is the most common type of skin cancer and presents with a localized lesion with a pearly rolled border and telangiectasia, not with erythroderma or circulating atypical T-cells.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Sézary syndrome is a leukemic variant of cutaneous T-cell lymphoma presenting with erythroderma, generalized lymphadenopathy, and the presence of atypical T-cells with cerebriform nuclei in the peripheral blood and skin.

 

Ref: Rooks’ Textbook of Dermatology- 9th Edition Page No 140.18

questions.text: Sezary Syndrome presents with all of the following EXCEPT?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Hypoanaesthetic Skin Patches

 

Option D:

 

  • Hypoanaesthetic skin patches are not a feature of Sézary syndrome; this is more suggestive of leprosy.

 

Explanation:

 

Sézary Syndrome

 

  • It is an aggressive form of cutaneous T-cell lymphoma characterized by erythroderma, lymphadenopathy, and the presence of malignant T-cells in the skin.
  • Sézary syndrome typically presents with intense pruritus (Itching) rather than Sensory Loss.

 

 

Sezary Cells: Atypical circulating T-cells with cerebriform nuclei

 

Sezary Syndrome → Triad: (SLE)

 

  1. Circulating Sezary cells (atypical mononuclear cells) >20% of Total Lymphocyte Count or 1000 X 109/L
  2. Generalized Lymphadenopathy (due to lymphoid infiltration)
  3. Erythroderma (4th stage of mycosis fungoides)

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Sézary syndrome is characterized by the presence of Sezary cells, lymphadenopathy, and erythroderma, but it does not present with hypoanaesthetic skin patches, which are more characteristic of leprosy.

 

Ref: Rooks Textbook of Dermatology- 9th Edition Page No 140.18

questions.text: Which of the following is NOT a cutaneous marker of underlying internal malignancy?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Erythema Chronicum Migrans

 

Option D:

 

  • Erythema chronicum migrans is not typically a marker of internal malignancy; it is the characteristic rash associated with early Lyme disease, which is caused by the tick-borne bacterium Borrelia burgdorferi.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Necrolytic migratory erythema:

 

  • Necrolytic migratory erythema is often associated with glucagonoma, which is a type of pancreatic islet cell tumor, making it a marker of underlying internal malignancy.

 

Option B. Acanthosis nigricans:

 

  • Acanthosis nigricans can be a cutaneous marker of internal malignancies, most commonly gastric adenocarcinoma.

 

Option C. Erythroderma:

 

  • Erythroderma can be associated with various internal conditions, including lymphoma and leukemia.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Erythema chronicum migrans is not a cutaneous marker of internal malignancy but is associated with Lyme disease.
  • In contrast, necrolytic migratory erythema, acanthosis nigricans, and erythroderma can all be cutaneous markers of various internal malignancies.

 

Ref: Rooks Textbook of Dermatology- 9th Edition Page No 147.1

choices.text: Asymmetry of Shape of Lesion

questions.text: All of the following are risk factors for a pigmented lesion to progress to Malignant Melanoma EXCEPT?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Diameter > 4 mm

 

Option D:

 

  • While the traditional teaching has been that moles with a diameter larger than 6 mm (about the size of a pencil eraser) are more likely to be melanomas, a diameter greater than 4 mm is not the standard measure of risk.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Asymmetry of shape of lesion:

 

  • Asymmetry is a risk factor for melanoma, as benign moles are generally symmetrical.

 

Option B. Irregular, scalloped border:

 

  • Moles with irregular, scalloped, or poorly defined borders are more likely to be malignant melanomas than those with smooth, even borders.

 

Option C. Variegation of colour:

 

  • Multiple colors or an uneven distribution of color can be a warning sign of malignant melanoma.

 

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • While asymmetry, irregular borders, and variegated colors are risk factors for the progression of pigmented lesions to malignant melanoma, a diameter greater than 4 mm is not the classic criterion for risk; rather, it is a diameter greater than 6 mm that is concerning.

 

Ref: Rook's Textbook of Dermatology - 9th Edition - Volume IV, Chapter 143 Page Nos 143.2, 143.16

choices.text: They appear as "Translucent" or "Pearly" Papules
Moh's Microscopic Surgery gives best results
Relatively Early Nodal involvement is classically seen
Noduloulcerative variant is the most common type of BCC

questions.text: Identify the INCORRECT statement related to basal cell carcinoma
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Relatively Early Nodal involvement is classically seen

 

Option C:

 

  • Basal cell carcinoma classically does not show early nodal involvement; it rarely metastasizes but can be locally aggressive.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. They appear as "translucent" or "pearly" papules:

 

  • Basal cell carcinomas (BCC) often appear as translucent or pearly papules, which may have telangiectatic vessels on the surface.

 

Option B. Moh's microscopic surgery gives best results:

 

  • Mohs micrographic surgery is considered the treatment of choice for BCC in critical areas because it offers the highest cure rate by allowing for the assessment of 100% of the peripheral margins.

 

Option D. Noduloulcerative variant is the most common type of BCC:

 

  • The noduloulcerative or nodular type is indeed the most common variant of basal cell carcinoma, often presenting as a pearly nodule with a central ulceration or depression, sometimes referred to as a "rodent ulcer."

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Basal cell carcinoma typically presents as a translucent or pearly papule, is best treated with Mohs micrographic surgery, and the noduloulcerative type is the most common.
  • Unlike other skin cancers, BCC rarely metastasizes and does not usually involve lymph nodes early in its course.

 

Ref: Rooks Textbook of Dermatology- 9th Edition Page No 141.8

questions.text: Malignant Transformation to Melanoma is commonly seen in?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Large Congenital Melanocytic Nevus

 

Option C.

 

  • Large congenital melanocytic nevi, especially those over 20 cm (giant congenital melanocytic nevus), have a higher risk of developing melanoma over the individual's lifetime, particularly if they are larger or have a nodular component.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Dermal nevus:

 

  • Dermal nevi are typically benign and less likely to transform into melanoma compared to congenital melanocytic nevi.

 

Option B. Compound nevus:

 

  • Compound nevi have Nevus cells in both the epidermis and dermis.
  • They have a slight risk of malignant transformation, but it is not as high as in large congenital melanocytic nevi.

 

Option D. Beckers nevus:

 

  • Becker's nevus is a benign cutaneous hamartoma that is usually not associated with malignant transformation.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • The large congenital melanocytic nevus presents a higher risk for malignant transformation to melanoma compared to other types of nevi, necessitating regular monitoring for changes suggestive of malignancy.

 

Ref: Rook's Textbook of Dermatology - 9th Edition - Volume IV, Chapter 143 Page Nos 143.2, 143.16

choices.text: BCC is the most common Skin Malignancy
SCC occurs in Sun Exposed and also over Sun protected sites including Mucosae
SCC is Most Common in Transplant Recipients

questions.text: Identify the FALSE statement among the following options?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) SCC has Pearly Rolled Edges

 

Option D.

 

  • The description of "pearly rolled edges" typically refers to Basal Cell Carcinoma, not Squamous Cell Carcinoma. SCC often presents as a scaly or crusted lesion with a potential for ulceration, rather than with the pearly appearance associated with BCC.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. BCC is the most common skin malignancy:

 

  • Basal Cell Carcinoma (BCC) is indeed the most common form of skin cancer.

 

Option B. SCC occurs in sun exposed and also over sun protected sites including mucosae:

 

  • Squamous Cell Carcinoma (SCC) can occur on sun-exposed skin, such as the head, neck, and arms, as well as in sun-protected areas and mucosal surfaces.

 

Option C. SCC is Most common in Transplant recipients:

 

  • SCC is more common in transplant recipients due to immunosuppression, which increases the risk of various skin cancers.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • The edges of a lesion can provide critical diagnostic clues; in the case of Basal Cell Carcinoma, "pearly rolled edges" are characteristic, whereas Squamous Cell Carcinoma typically does not present with such a feature.

 

Ref: Rooks’ Textbook of Dermatology- 9th Edition Page No 141.8, 142.25
